SparseEnv 0.0.1
  • Functions
  • Changelog

    Fit the sparse envelope model.

    spenv.Rd

    Fit the sparse envelope model.

    Usage

    spenv(
  X,
  Y,
  u,
  lambda1 = NULL,
  lambda2 = NULL,
  ftol = 1e-04,
  maxiter = 100,
  verbose = 0,
  init = NULL
)

    Arguments

    X

    Predictors. An n by p matrix, p is the number of predictors. The predictors can be univariate or multivariate, discrete or continuous.

    Y

    Multivariate responses. An n by r matrix, r is the number of responses and n is the number of observations. The responses must be continuous variables.

    u

    Dimension of the envelope. An integer between 0 and r.

    lambda1

    A user-supplied lambda sequence for the first stage.

    lambda2

    A user-supplied lambda sequence for the second stage.

    ftol

    Tolerance parameter for F. Default value: 1e-4.

    maxiter

    Maximum number of iterations. Default value: 100.

    verbose

    Flag for printing out the model fitting process, logical 0 or 1. Default value: 0.

    init

    The initial value for the envelope subspace. An r by u matrix. The default value is the one generated by the function initial_value.

    Value

    alpha

    The estimated intercept in the envelope model. An r by 1 vector.

    beta

    The envelope estimator of the regression coefficients. An r by p matrix.

    Gamma

    The orthogonal basis of the envelope subspace. An r by u semi-orthogonal matrix.

    Gamma0

    The orthogonal basis of the complement of the envelope subspace. An r by r-u semi-orthogonal matrix.

    eta

    The coordinates of beta with respect to Gamma. A u by p matrix.

    Sigma

    The envelope estimator of the error covariance matrix. An r by r matrix.

    Omega

    The coordinates of Sigma with respect to Gamma. A u by u matrix.

    Omega0

    The coordinates of Sigma with respect to Gamma0. An r-u by r-u matrix.

    loglik

    The maximized log likelihood function. A real number.

    paramNum

    The number of parameters in the envelope model. A positive integer.

    sigRes

    The sample error covariance matrix. An r by r matrix.

    sigY

    The sample response covariance matrix. An r by r matrix.

    sigX

    The sample predictor covariance matrix. A p by p matrix.

    n

    The number of observations in the data. A positive integer.

    r

    The number of responses. A nonnegative integer.

    u

    Dimension of the envelope. An integer between 0 and r.

    p

    The number of predictors. A positive integer.

    q

    The number of active responses. A positive integer.

    where_1

    The active responses chosen by the sparse envelope model.

    where_0

    The inactive responses chosen by the sparse envelope model.

    lambda

    The tuning parameters chosen by BIC.

    BIC_seq1

    The sequence of BIC in the first stage.

    BIC_seq2

    The sequence of BIC in the second stage.

    fit_time

    The time costs for fitting the sparse envelope model.

    Details

    This function fits the sparse envelope model to the responses using maximum likelihood estimation. When the dimension of the envelope is between 1 and r-1, we implement the algorithm in Su Z, Zhu G, Chen X, and Yang Y (2016). When the dimension is r, the envelope model degenerates to standard multivariate linear regression. When the dimension is 0, it means that X and Y are uncorrelated, and the fitting is different.

    References

    The codes are implemented based on the algorithm in Su, Z., Zhu, G., Chen, X., and Yang, Y. (2016), Sparse Envelope Model: Efficient Estimation and Response Variable Selection in Multivariate Linear Regression. Biometrika. 103, 579-593.

    See also

    choose_spenv for choosing the dimension of the envelope subspace and the tuning parameter.

    Author

    Guangyu Zhu guangyuzhu@uri.edu

    Examples

    ## Berkeley
data(Berkeley)
X = Berkeley$X
Y2 = Berkeley$Y[, c(1, 2, 21, 23)]
m1 = spenv(X, Y2, 1)
asym.spenv(m1)
#> $covMatrix
#>      [,1] [,2]      [,3]      [,4]
#> [1,]    0    0  0.000000  0.000000
#> [2,]    0    0  0.000000  0.000000

#> [4,]    0    0 -3.054445  3.323175
#>

#> [1,] 0.000000
#> [2,] 0.000000
#> [3,] 1.835140
#> [4,] 1.822958
#>

#> [2,]      Inf
